body.p: The following functions are provided by the package manager to handle various install-related tasks. ${ED} is prepended automatically to the install location.

The do* functions, when given multiple arguments, will work upon multiple targets. The new* functions take exactly two arguments (except as noted) the first is the source name, the second the name to use when installing.
The *into functions create the directory if it does not already exist.

tr.ti: Change install location for dobin, newbin, dosbin, newsbin, dolib, dolib.a, newlib.a, dolib.so, newlib.so
Change install location for doins, newins
Change install location for doexe, newexe
Change install location for dodoc, newdoc
Specify arguments passed to install (eg -s, -m644)
Specify arguments passed to install for directories
Specify arguments passed to install for executables
Specify arguments passed to install for libraries Note: Banned in EAPI=7

Install a binary into subdirectory bin of the location provided by into (resulting in /usr/bin by default) with mode 0755 and with ownership set to superuser or its equivalent on the system or installation at hand
Install an /etc/conf.d file
Install a directory that will be non-empty when the package is merged. For directories that will be empty, please use keepdir instead.
Install a documentation file into /usr/share/doc/${PF}. The -r option allows directories to be installed recursively.
Installs the files and directories specified by the DOCS and HTML_DOCS variables into /usr/share/doc/${PF} recursively using dodoc -r. Note: Approved in EAPI 6.
Install an /etc/env.d file
Install an executable into the location provided by exeinto, by default with mode 0755 or with the install options set by exeopts
Install a header file into /usr/include. The -r option allows directories to be installed recursively.

Installs HTML document files into /usr/share/doc/${PF}/html The -r option allows directories to be installed recursively. Note: Deprecated in EAPI 6, switch to einstalldocs instead. Note: Banned in EAPI=7
Install a GNU Info document
Install an /etc/init.d file
Install a miscellaneous file. The -r option allows directories to be installed recursively. Any symlinks encountered are installed as symlinks, when installing recursively.
Install a library file Note: Banned in EAPI=7
Install a library (.a) file
Install a library (shared object) file

ti.p: Install a man page into the appropriate section of /usr/share/man. e.g., foo.1 will be installed in /usr/share/man/man1/foo.1.

If the man page is named foo.<lang>.1 then it will be installed in /usr/share/man/<lang>/man1/foo.1, where <lang> is a language code. Option -i18n=<lang> can be used to explicitly specify a subdirectory (or to suppress it, if empty).

tr.ti: Install a Gettext .mo file. (EAPI=7) No longer looks at the value of into
Install an sbin/ file

Create a symlink to the target specified as the first parameter, at the path specified by the second parameter. Note that the target is interpreted verbatim; it needs to either specify a relative path or an absolute path including ${EPREFIX}.
Call chown on the specified files in ${ED}
Call chmod on the specified files in ${ED}

Install a directory that will be empty when the package is merged. This is like dodir, but for empty directories instead. The handling of empty directories is undefined by the package manager specification, and the keepdir function exists to ensure that the (otherwise empty) directory is tracked. This is accomplished by installing a hidden file prefixed with .keep to the directory in question.

Controls compression of files. Normally executed to exclude from compression, e.g., docompress -x /usr/share/doc/${PF}/examples.

Introduced with EAPI=7, controls the stripping of executables. Normally executed to exclude from stripping. Eg. dostrip -x /path/to/important.so. May also be used to include binaries to strip when RESTRICT=strip without the -x option. Provided paths are relative to ${ED}, even if they begin with a slash.
